STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 15, 2019
Irene Waller
Tuscola County DHHS
1365 Cleaver Rd
Caro, MI 48723
RE: License #: CP790201478
Tuscola County DHHS
1365 Cleaver Rd
Caro, MI 48723
Dear Mrs. Waller:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
1/22/19. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions.
Sincerely,
James B. Gale, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 296-4814
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP790201478
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Irene Waller, Administrator
Herman McCall, Designee
Name of Facility: Tuscola County DHHS
Facility Address: 1365 Cleaver Rd
Caro, MI 48723
Facility Telephone #: (989) 673-9207
Original Issuance Date: 08/01/1992
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
1

Date of On-site Inspection(s): 1/15/19 – 1/22/19

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) If the responsibility for the child’s case moves from one agency to another, there
must be some kind of new plan in the child’s file within 30 calendar days after the
change. It does not have to be a complete Service Plan, but must address why the
case was transferred, whether the new worker/agency agrees with the previous case
plans, and any changes since the last plan was written. History from previous plans
may be referenced in this plan.
(4) The agency must document that the service plan was reviewed and provided to
the foster parents. Documentation may be in social work contacts or by the foster
parent signing a document acknowledging that the plan was reviewed and a copy
received.
One of sixteen service plans was late. The assigned case manager was out on an
unexpected leave. The agency has been effective in completing service plans timely.
This rule has not been cited during the previous three (2018, 2017, 2016) reviews. A
corrective action plan is required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 5.1 – Page 14 Caseload Progressions for New Employees (Commitment
23).
b. For foster care and adoption workers, three training cases may be assigned on or
after day one of pre-service training at the supervisor’s discretion using CWTI case
assignments guidelines. After completion of week three of pre-service training, up to
five total cases may be assigned with supervisory approval using CWTI case
assignment guidelines. Final caseload may be assigned after nine weeks.
One of three case managers hired since the last review was assigned cases on the
pre-service registration date not on or after the first date of training. The supervisor
was not clear on the language of this requirement. A corrective action plan is required.
ISEP 6.16.3 - Page 23 Relative Foster Parents (Commitment 52).
(a) When placing a child with a relative who has not been previously licensed as a
4

foster parent DHHS shall:
(3) within 30 days, complete a home study determining whether the relative should,
upon completion of training and submission of any other required documents, be
licensed as a foster parent.
The 3130a for one unlicensed relative care giver was completed after 60 days. A
corrective action plan is required.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 722-6H – Page 7 Unannounced Home Visit CASEWORKER
CONTACT WITH CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in the caregiver’s home
each calendar month. If there are two caregivers, such as a primary and secondary
caregiver, the caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the secondary
caregiver in the home at least once each quarter. The caseworker must make an
unannounced visit to the home every quarter. The unannounced visit must be
documented in MiSACWIS.
Sixteen service plans were reviewed. Three unannounced home visits were not
completed as required. The required monthly home visits were conducted as
scheduled visits. This is a repeat violation from the 2018 interim inspection.
.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C Page 2 Required Participation in Development -
Foster Parent / Caregiver
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver to meet the specific
individual needs of the child placed in their home are included in the PATP. The foster
parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP process. The foster parent/caregiver
signature is required and indicates that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges
and agrees to the activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities provided by the foster care
worker to assist the foster parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
Sixteen service plans were reviewed. The required PATPs were not signed by both
care givers for three service plans. It should be noted that social work contacts by the
assigned case manager documented the engagement of the caregivers in the
development of the service plan. This is a repeat violation from the 2018 interim
inspection. A corrective action plan is required.
5

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
6

DCWL Analyst report
The DCWL analyst between the dates of 10/30/18 – 11/15/18 visited three foster
homes and two unlicensed relative homes completing nine interviews. The findings
of these interviews are documented below.
Safety and concern alert # 1
The home smells very strongly of cigarette smoke. The foster parent states she
smokes outside.
The agency responded there are no children placed in this home is closed.
Safety and concern alert # 2
A child under the age of 5 is placed in the home. The home needs plug covers in the
electrical outlets.
One bedroom used by household members has twin bed headboards blocking the
windows in the bedroom. The windows are the second means of egress for the
bedroom.
The agency responded that the family has rearranged the bedroom. They have set
bunk beds up and have put a crib in the room. The window is not blocked. Outlet
plugs have been put back on. Pictures document these changes.
Safety and concern alert # 3
A room used as a bedroom does not have a second means of egress. The room is
currently occupied by a child that is adopted and has special emotional needs. The
foster parent states there is an approved safety plan for the use of this bedroom.
The agency responded that the adopted son has moved into another bedroom, with a
second means of egress. A picture documents this change.
Safety and concern alert # 4
A birth mother reported she was not given the opportunity to give input into the
treatment plan. She was directed as to what she had to do.
The relative caregiver needs medical insurance cards for both children in the home.
The agency responded that the mother spoke with the analyst on 8/15/18 regarding
services and was able to give her input. The contact is in the service plan. She signed
the initial court report giving the services. She went over with her attorney what the
services were and they both agreed upon them and was read into the record on
9/11/18. On 11/13/18 during a home visit to the mother by the interim case manager
the services were reviewed and included the mother’s input.
7

The assigned case manager was never made aware the caregiver never received
medical cards. Cards were ordered once it was known caregiver was missing
insurance cards at the 10/25/18 home visit. Contact was made with the HLO right
away on 10/25/18, and the cards were ordered. They were given to the caregiver on
11/27/18 as the worker was off on medical leave and the cards arrived 11/15/18.
The agency also reported to this consultant that the DHS 3762 (temporary medical
authorization card)- Consent to Routine, Non-surgical, medical care and emergency
medical/treatment card was provided by CPS on the date of removal, 7/3/2018 to the
caregiver for both children.
Safety and concern alert # 5
The bedroom used by the child placed in the home is a tandem bedroom and is used
as a passthrough by another household member to get to and from their bedroom.
The relative caretakers were unaware of possible financial assistance available to
them to care for the child placed in the home. For example, the ineligible grant.
The relative caretaker does not have a medical passport for the child placed in the
home.
The agency responded that the bedroom where the child resides with another
bedroom where the 17-year-old cousin resides. Agency certification staff that the
arrangement is not a rule violation. The two youth are cousins and close in age. The
arrangement would be the same as 2 teenage girls sharing a room which is permitted
by licensing rule. This arrangement gives each girl more privacy.
Upon initial placement of the child in the home, ineligible grantee was discussed as
well as them getting them licensed. Initially the relatives were going to get licensed
and were not concerned with ineligible grantee monies. The relative caretakers have
been extremely indecisive in the whole licensing process. The licensing worker has
had several contacts with the relatives where they indicated they wanted to get
licensed and then cancelled the appointment or stated they call back and never did.
The agency currently has a signed waiver they signed in November.
The agency reported a medical passport was not given to them. It is believed the
relatives meant to say they do not have medical cards. They do not have medical
cards due to choosing United Health Care once the child returned to the community.
The insurance card was not accepted by the child’s therapist. The child did not want
to change therapists. HLO staff has facilitated the selection of another health plan that
would cover therapy. Coverage began on 12/1/18. A signed medical passport
documented the passport was provided at the child’s placement.
8

EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for violations identified in the 3/22/18
annual inspections. The agency’s compliance their 2018 corrective action plan is
detailed below under Interim Licensing Inspection 3/22/18.
Interim licensing inspection 3/22/18
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Three of eight reevaluations reviewed were not completed at
least 15 days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
This renewal inspection found the agency compliant with this
rule.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who have
children placed in the home shall be notified there is a
corrective action plan and what is required of the foster
parent in that plan.
In one of two special evaluations reviewed there was no
documentation that the assigned social worker was provided
with a copy of the corrective action plan.
This renewal inspection found the agency compliant with this
rule.
9

R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(1) An agency shall develop service plans with the child,
the child's parents or legal guardian, the referring agency,
and the other parties involved in providing needed
services, or medical care, unless the agency documents
why any of the entities have not been involved.
In two of twelve service plans reviewed there was not adequate
documentation that the child’s parent was involved in the
development of the service plan.
This renewal inspection found the agency compliant with this
rule.
ISEP 6.33(c) Page 28 Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the caseworker’s supervisor, the
parent(s), and the child(ren), if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall include an explanation
of the steps taken to involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to
secure their participation in services.
In four of twelve service plans reviewed the birth parents did not sign a PATP. In one of
three service plans requiring a child’s signature it was not obtained. This is also a DHHS
Policy FOM 722-08c requirement.
This renewal inspection found the agency compliant with this policy.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and service agreement, the
parent is given a copy for review. Foster care workers need to ensure the parent
understands all areas within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the PATP,
foster care workers must identify and document additional action needed to secure
the parent’s and/or youth’s participation in service planning and compliance with
the PATP. As the goals are achieved, modified or expanded, the updated PATP will
reflect this process. Parents and youths age 14 and older must participate in the
development of each updated treatment plan, allowing for opportunity to evaluate
their progress towards completing goals.
10

In four of twelve service plans reviewed the birth parents did not sign a PATP. In one of
three service plans requiring a child’s signature it was not obtained. This is also an ISEP
6.33 c requirement.
This renewal inspection found the agency compliant with policy.
The foster parent is required to sign each parent agency treatment plan.
In four of twelve service plans reviewed there was no documentation the foster parent
signed the PATP.
This renewal inspection found in three of sixteen service plans both foster parents did not
sign the PATP. This is a repeat violation. Social work contacts documented the assigned
case manager engaged the foster parents in the development of the service plan.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H Page 10 CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH PARENT(S)/
GUARDIAN(S)
During the first month of out of home placement the case manager must have two
face to face contacts with each parent at least one must be at the parent’s
residence.
In two separate cases the assigned case manager did not clearly document efforts to
make a home call to the parent’s residence.
This renewal inspection found the agency compliant with this policy.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-6H – Unannounced Home Visit .CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in the caregiver’s home
each calendar month. If there are two caregivers, such as a primary and secondary
caregiver, the caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the secondary
caregiver in the home at least once each quarter. The caseworker must make an
unannounced visit to the home every quarter. The unannounced visit must be
documented in MiSACWIS.
In two of eight service plan periods requiring an unannounced home visit the requirement
was not met.
The renewal inspection found in three of sixteen service plans the required unannounced
home visit was not conducted. This is a repeat violation. The monthly visit was conducted
as a scheduled visit.
DHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport must be provided to
the foster parent within two weeks of the child’s placement.
11

The initial medical passport in two of seven cases reviewed was not provided timely to
the care givers to meet the two-week requirement of this rule.
This renewal inspection found the agency compliant with this policy.
.
.
.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
2/15/19
________________________________________
James B. Gale Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 25, 2019
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
